turns.speaker: NIKI
turns.text: You can fuck off, too.

turns.speaker: MAST
turns.text: You're taking a big chance.

turns.speaker: NIKI
turns.text: I ain't ever gonna see him again anyway.

turns.speaker: MAST
turns.text: Oh no? What you gonna do? Get a job?

turns.speaker: NIKI
turns.text: Jake'll take care of me.

turns.speaker: MAST
turns.text: Who? Van Dorn? You must be kidding yourself, honey. You think once that guy finds his daughter he'll care about you?

turns.speaker: RAMADA
turns.text: Hey, piss-head, what brings you around?

turns.speaker: MAST
turns.text: You don't have to get uppity with me, Bill. I remember when you was running that car wash and couldn't make it go. And what was that other thing you tried? A Dairy Queen? Went busted too.

turns.speaker: RAMADA
turns.text: At least I improved myself. What's up?

turns.speaker: MAST
turns.text: I want you to take a look at this girl here. She's been in some porn stuff.

turns.speaker: RAMADA
turns.text: No, Andy. Don't know the kid.

turns.speaker: MAST
turns.text: Look again, Billy-boy. This is jail bait. Could get you in a lotta trouble.

turns.speaker: RAMADA
turns.text: Nope never saw her before.  Kurt, come over here. Don't use underage kids. Wouldn't touch 'em for all the cow shit in Mexico.  You recognize this piece of wool, Kurt?

turns.speaker: NIKI
turns.text: You remember me. Louise? Rhymes with squeeze.

turns.speaker: RUCKER
turns.text: You working in San Diego now?

turns.speaker: NIKI
turns.text: I'm still in L.A., but I'm looking for Tod. I heard he was around.

turns.speaker: RUCKER
turns.text: 'Was.' He and that shitheel Ratan went down to T-J. Maybe I shouldn't say that. Anyway, I hear he's back in Frisco now.

turns.speaker: NIKI
turns.text: Was he with a girl?

turns.speaker: RUCKER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NIKI
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Hello, I'm Candy Gulf.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: How do you do. I'm Mrs. Chasen. Come in.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: You are at the University, Candy?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: And what are you studying?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Poli. Sci. With a home ec minor.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Eh, Poli Sci?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Political Science. It's all about what's going on.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: He seems very nice. Is Harold interested in, eh, what's going on? I think it's such a super thing to study. And then, of course, I can always fall back on home ec.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Yes, that's good planning. Tell me, are you a regular, Candy, in this computer club?

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: I think I should mention, Candy, that Harold does have his eccentric moments.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Oh, <u>yes</u>? Well, that's all right. I've got a brother who's a real cut-up, too. I'll never forget the time we had this old TV set with no parts in it. Well, Tommy stuck his head behind it and started giving a newscast before the whole family. We were all hysterical. And here's little Tommy pretending to be Walter Cronkite.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Lady, you were going 70 miles an hour in a 45-mile zone. Could I see your license, please?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes. Those little pieces of paper with your picture on it?

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, I don't have one.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Come again.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I don't have one. I don't believe in them.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: How long have you been driving?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: About forty-five minutes, wouldn't you say, Harold? We were hoping to start sooner but, you see, it's rather hard to find a truck.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Could I see your registration?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I just don't think we have one, unless it's in the glove compartment. Could you look, Harold?

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Isn't this your vehicle?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: No, no. I just took it.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Took it?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes. You see I have to plant my tree.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Your tree.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, it's not really mine. I dug it up in front of the courthouse. We're transplanting it. Letting it breathe, you know. But, of course, we would like to get it into soil, as soon as possible.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Lady, let me get this straight.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: All right, then, and we'll be off.  Nice chatting with you.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Okay, lady. Out.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Haven't we met before?

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: None of that, lady.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, well. Must have been your brother.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Out!

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: But there is a family resemblance.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: You too, Buster. Stand over here. Lady, you're in a heap of trouble. I have you down here for several violations; speeding, resisting arrest, driving without a license, driving a stolen vehicle, possession of a stolen tree... Where's the tree?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: We planted it.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Is this your shovel?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Possession of a stolen shovel.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Officer, I can explain.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Lady, resisting arrest is a serious criminal offense. Under the state criminal code, section 545, paragraph 10-B...

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, don't get officious. You're not yourself when you're officious. That's the curse of a government job.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Lady, is it true you're driving without a license?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Check.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: And that truck - is it registered in your name?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh no! Not in <u>my</u> name.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Then whose name is it registered in?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, I don't know. Do you know, Harold?

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Where are the papers?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I suppose they are in the truck. Are you going to take a lot of time with this?

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Wait here.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Because if you are...

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: Lady! Be quiet.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: This way, Edith. Harold is out by the garage. He has a new car and he has been tuning it up. He's very mechanical.

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: What kind of a car is it?

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: Oh. It looks like a hearse.  Very nice. Compact.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Edith, I'd like you to meet my son, Harold. Harold, this is Edith... eh?

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: Fern. I'm very pleased to make your acquaintance.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: And what do you do, my dear?

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: I'm a file clerk - Harrison Feed and Grain.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: How interesting.

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: Not very.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Oh. Well, what is it exactly that you do?

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: I'm in charge of all the invoices for the southwest. We supply, for example, most of the egg farmers in Southern California. So you can imagine.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Edith was just telling me about her job.

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: I'm a file clerk.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Yes. Henderson Feed and Grain.

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: Harrison. Harrison Feed and Grain... At Hamilton and Fourth... I'm in charge of the invoices... And I type up the schedule for the trucking fleet...

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: She supplies the whole southwest with chicken feed.

turns.speaker: EDITH
turns.text: Well, not all the southwest. Although we do have a large business... Barley was very big last week...  Fifteen hundred...

turns.speaker: GLAUCUS
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm sorry. I was looking for Maude.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Sorry I'm late.

turns.speaker: GLAUCUS
turns.text: A rather free translation but nonetheless correct. Greetings to you too, my little one.  Tell me, what do you see?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: A block of ice.

turns.speaker: GLAUCUS
turns.text: Exactly! Now, ask me what I see.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What do you see?

turns.speaker: GLAUCUS
turns.text: I see the eternal goddess of beauty and love. I see Aphrodite. The consummate woman.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Here's your shovel.

turns.speaker: GLAUCUS
turns.text: What?... Oh yes... Shovel... Create ... Verily these issues lie in the lap of the gods... Iliad... Just sit down for a minute.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Eh, no. Thank you.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: You're welcome.  Did you know him?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Eh, no.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Me neither. I heard he was eighty years old. I'll be eighty next week. A good time to move on, don't you think?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I mean, seventy-five is too early, but at eighty-five, well, you're just marking time and you may as well look over the horizon.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: It's a question of emphasis, you might say. Accentuate the positive, so to speak.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Eh, could I have my pen back now, please?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, of course. What is your name?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Harold Chasen.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: How do you do? I am Dame Marjorie Chardin, but you may call me Maude.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Nice to meet you.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, thank you. I think we shall be great friends, don't you?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Can I drop you anywhere, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No, thank you. I have my car.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well then, I must be off.  We shall have to meet again.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Do you dance?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Do you sing and dance?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Eh, no.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: No.  I thought not.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, so do I. They're such fun, aren't they? It's all change. All revolving. Burials and births. The end to the beginning and the beginning to the end -  - the great circle of life. My, this old thing handles well. Ever drive a hearse, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, it's a new experience for me.  Good on curves. Shall I take you home, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But this is my car.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Your hearse?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yearse!

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Of course, I've had to make some additions for the new models, but not as many as you might think. Once you have your basic set it's then only a question of variation.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And you get into any car you want and just drive off?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Not <u>any</u> car. I like to keep a variety. I'm always looking for the new experience, like this one. I liked it.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Thank you. But when you take these cars don't you think you are wronging the owners?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: What owners, Harold? We don't <u>own</u> anything. It's a transitory world. We come on the earth with nothing, and we go out with nothing, so isn't "ownership" a little absurd?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Still, I think you'd upset people and I'm not sure that's right.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, if some people are upset because they feel they have a hold on some things, then I'm merely acting as a gentle reminder - I'm sort of breaking it easy -- Here today, gone tomorrow, so don't get attached to <u>things</u>. Now, with that in mind, I'm not against collecting stuff...

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: It's all memorabilia, but incidental and not integral, if you know what I mean.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's very interesting.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, look! The birds.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: She's very sweet, but so old- fashioned. Please sit down, Harold. I'll put on the kettle and we'll have a nice hot cup of tea.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Thank you, but I really have to go.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: But it's oat straw tea. You've never had oat straw tea, have you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well then.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Thank you, but it's an appointment. I really shouldn't miss it.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, at the dentist's?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Sort of.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, then, you must come back and visit.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: My door is always open.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Promise?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Maude???!

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: How about some ginger pie?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Eh, fine.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I'll heat some up. My, it's nice to see you again, Harold. How's your hearse?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh, it's fine. Fine.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: She seemed yare to me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Do you often model for Glaucus?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Heavens no! I don't have the time. But I like to keep in practice and poor Glaucus occasionally needs his memory refreshed as to the contours of the female form.  Do you disapprove?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Me! No. Of course not.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Really. Do you think it's wrong?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, I'm so happy you said that because I wanted to show you my paintings. This is the "Rape of Rome" and, of course, there in the corner is quite a graphic depiction of Leda and the Swan.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: A self-portrait.  But over here is my favorite. It's titled "Rainbow with Egg Underneath and an Elephant." Do you like it?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes. Very much.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: It was my last. I then became infatuated with these -- my "Odorifics."

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Now I'll pump it up...  ... and you just turn the handles.  Okay. What do you smell?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Subways... Perfume... Cigarette...  ... Cologne... Carpet... Chestnuts! ... <u>Snow!</u>

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: It goes on and on.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's really great.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh. Eh, I like it.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: No, you have to touch it.  You have to run your hands over it, get close to it, really reach out and feel. You try it.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Here we are, Harold. Oat straw tea and ginger pie.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Certainly a new experience for me.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Wonderful! Try something new each day. After all, we're given life to find it out. It doesn't last forever.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You look as if you could.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Me. Ha! Did I tell you I'll be eighty on Saturday?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You don't look eighty.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: That's the influence of the right food, the right exercise, and the right breathing.  Greet the dawn with the Breath of Fire!  Of course, there's no doubt the body is giving out. I'm well into autumn. I'll have to be giving it all up after Saturday. Sweeten the tea with honey, Harold. It's delicious.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's a nice teapot.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Sterling silver. It was my dear mother-in-law's, part of a dinner set of fifty pieces. It's one of the few things that survived.  Oh, but I do rattle on so. Tell me about yourself, Harold.  What do you do when you aren't visiting funerals?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, it's all very thrilling, of course, but I ask you, Harold... Is it enough?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I should like to change into a sunflower most of all. They are so <u>tall</u> and simple. And you, Harold, what flower would you like to be?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't know. Just one of those.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Why do you say that?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Because they are all the same.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oooh, but they are not. Look.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Boy, Maude. The way you handle cars. I'd never handle a car like that.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, it's only a machine, Harold. It's not as if it were <u>alive</u>, like a horse or a camel. We may live in a machine age, but I simply can't treat them as equals.  Of course, the age has its advantages.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: The universal language of mankind.  What music do you like, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Look.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Over there by the courthouse.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: That little tree. It's in trouble. Come on.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Look at it, Harold. It's suffocating. It's the smog. People can live with it, but it gives trees asthma. They can't breathe. See the leaves are all brown. Harold, we've got to do something about this life.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But what?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: We'll transplant it. To the forest.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But we can't just dig it up!

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But this is public property.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Don't you think we should get some tools, maybe?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes, you're right. We'll go see Glaucus. Come on.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh, wait, Maude. Look!

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, my. We're too late.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Is he all right?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: He's fallen asleep, as usual.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: We'll come back in the morning.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What is that he's working on?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: An ice sculpture. It's Venus - the Goddess of Love, the completion of which is his unfulfilled dream.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It is kind of rough.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: He's never finished one yet. He has around him every kind of hand tool known to man, but the poor dear has difficulty staying awake.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Look, the ice is melting.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: A little after-dinner liqueur, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, I really don't drink...

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, it's all right. It's organic.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Some nuts? Some licorice? It has no nutritional value but then consistency is not really a human trait.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: My umbrella?  Oh, that's just a relic. I found it when I was packing to come to America. It used to be my defense on picket lines and rallies and political meetings - being dragged off by police or attacked by thugs of the opposition.  A long time ago.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What were you fighting for?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, Big Issues. Liberty. Rights. Justice. Kings died and kingdoms fell. I don't regret the kingdoms - what sense in borders and nations and patriotism - but I do miss the kings. When I was a little girl I was taken to the palace in Vienna, to a garden party. I can still see the sunshine, the parasols, and the flashing uniforms of the young officers. I thought then I would marry a soldier.  Later, Frederick would chide me about it.  He was so serious. A doctor at the University. And in the government.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No more revolts.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, yes! Every day. But I don't need a defense anymore. I embrace! Still fighting for the Big Issues but now in my small, individual way. Shall we have a song?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, I don't...

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh come on. I'll teach you.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, that was fun. Let's play something together.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But I don't play anything.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Don't play anything! Dear me. Everyone should be able to make some music. Why, it's life! - Rhythm and harmony - That's the cosmic dance. Come with me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Okay?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Superb.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I think he's following us.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Is he? Ah, the police. Always wanting to play games. Well, here goes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He's stopped.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: The old double U-turn. Gets them every time.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: There. Oh, I like the feel of soil, don't you? And the smell. It's the earth. "The earth is my body. My head is in the stars."  Who said that?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I suppose I did.  Well, farewell little tree. Grow up tall, and change, and fall to replenish the earth. Isn't it wonderful, Harold? All around us. Living things.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, those motorcycles are awfully chilly.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yeah. And it is cold in here. Hello, Glaucus.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I <u>think</u> I see it.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes. It's almost there.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The ice is melting.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Don't you think we should turn off the heat?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Why? There'll be a new block of ice in the morning.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I like Glaucus.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes, so do I. But I think he is a little... old-fashioned. Like a puff, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, I really don't smoke.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: It's all right.  It's organic.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm sure picking up on vices.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Vice? Virtue? It's best not to be too moral. You cheat yourself out of too much life. Aim above morality. As Confucius says, "Don't simply be good. Make good things happen."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Did Confucius say that?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well --  - they say he was very wise, so I'm sure he must have.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You are the wisest person I know.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Me!  When I look around me I know I know nothing. I remember though, once long ago in Persia, we met a wise man in the bazaar. He was a professional and used to sell his wisdom to anyone willing to pay. His specialty for tourists was a maxim engraved on the head of a pin. "The wisest," he said, "the truest, the most instructive words for all men at all times." Frederick bought one for me and back at the hotel I peered through a magnifying glass to read the words - "And this too shall pass away."  Well, the wise man was right - if you remember that, you can't help but live life fully.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes. I haven't lived.  I've died a few times.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Died! Seventeen times - not counting maiming.  Shot myself in the face once with a popgun and a pellet of blood.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: How ingenious! Tell me about them.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, it's a question of timing, and the right equipment, and plenty of patience... You really want to hear about this?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes. I understand. A lot of people enjoy being dead. But they are not dead really. They're just backing away from life.  They're players - but they sit on the bench. The game goes on before them. At any moment they can join in.  Reach out! Take a chance! Get hurt maybe. But play as well as you can.  Go team, go! Give me an "L." Give me an "I."  Give me a "V." Give me an "E." LIVE!!!!!  Otherwise you'll have nothing to talk about in the locker room.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I like you, Maude.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I like you, Harold.  Come, I'll teach you to waltz.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Look at that sky.  It's so big.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: It's so blue.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And beyond the blue is the blackness of the cosmos.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Spreckled with uncountable stars. The stars are shining right now. We just can't see them. Just another instance of all that's going on that is beyond human perception.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Maude, do you pray?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Pray? No.  I communicate.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: With God?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: With Life.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: This is really nice. Makes me feel like a kid. I want to do somersaults .

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, why don't you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No. I'd feel stupid.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Harold, everyone has the right to make an ass out of themselves. You just can't let the world judge you too much.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Want to join me in some cartwheels?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: No. I feel more like - yodeling.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yodeling?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: It's sinking, Harold. Going over the horizon - where we are all going to go. It's getting dark. "Let each man hold on to his candle and get a light where'er he can."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Where's that?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: From the guys who got the matches, of course.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Boy! It sure has been a wonderful day. And you - you are beautiful.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, Harold. You make me feel like a schoolgirl.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Shall I drop by tomorrow?  Oh, I have a luncheon date. With this girl.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I've never met her. My mother set it up.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, be kind. I've lived a long time, Harold, seen evil as well as good, and it has been my experience that kindness...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Maude, I must speak to you.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: What is it, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: They're going to draft me. In the Army. I'm going to be sent away.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: But they can't do that. You haven't even got the vote.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But they have.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, don't go.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But they'll put me in jail.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Really. Just put it there, Harold.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: They'd put you in jail, eh? Well, historically you'd be in very good company.  That's what my husband used to say when we were in the French Underground dealing with the Gestapo. Would you like to do a little raking?  Work, I'm told, done with no selfish interest, purifies the mind. You sink your separate self and become one with the universal self. On the other hand, senseless labor is a bloody bore and should be scrupulously avoided.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Maude, do you think you can help me?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: What? With your skill and my experience... I think we can come up with something.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Don't you talk to me like that, you little foul mouth degenerate!  Really, sir, I thought that you at least...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Traitor! Benedict Arnold! Remember Nathan Hale, right, sir?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Don't you advance on me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: ... of you. You'll all end up like this.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Just like this.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Give me that.  I'm going to throw it in the sewer where it belongs.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She took my head.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That wasn't very scary.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: No. It had nothing on this afternoon.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh, you weren't scared.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Scared? Swimming underwater with that oxygen device of yours. I was petrified.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Come on, you loved it. It was a new experience.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How about some candy floss?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Right on! It wouldn't be a celebration without it.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You sure have a way with people.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, they're my species.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Look at the stars.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes. They're old friends.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Do you think there is any life up there?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I don't know. Perhaps.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Science thinks there isn't. That we are all alone in the universe.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: We <u>are</u> alone - you and me and everybody. But we can look at those stars and maybe someone down the beach or across the sea in China is looking at them, too. Someone we don't know and most likely will never see - that someone is breathing along with us. And the star- gazers of the past - from peasant to princes - and the star-gazers of the future - all of us breathing and looking up there. We are alone - but look at the stars and never feel lonely.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You should have been a poet.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, no. But I should have liked to have been an astronaut. A private astronaut able to just go out and explore. Like the men who sailed with Magellan, I want to see if we really can fall off the edge of the world.  What a joke it will be if like them I -

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: - end where I began.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Maude.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Why are there no photographs in these frames?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I took them out.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: They mocked me. They were representations of people I dearly loved yet they knew these people were gradually fading from me, and that in time all I would have left would be vague feelings - but sharp photographs! So I tossed them out. My memory fades, I know. But I prefer pictures made by me with feeling, and not by Kodak with silver nitrate.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'll never forget you, Maude.  But I would like a photo of you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It looks like you. Thanks.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Harold, that picture is almost twenty-five years old.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You haven't changed a bit. I'll put it in my wallet.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I was remembering how much this meant to me. It was after the war... I had nothing... except my life. How different I was then - and yet how the same.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You've never cried before. I never thought you would. I thought, despite anything, you could always be happy.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, Harold. You are so young.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Supper for two.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, you've thought of everything. And champagne.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's all right. It's organic.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, Harold.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: For you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: ... which I hope will make you very happy.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, I am happy, Harold. Ecstatically happy. I couldn't imagine a lovelier farewell.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Farewell?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Why yes. It's my eightieth birthday.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But you're not going anywhere, are you?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh yes, dear. I took the pills an hour ago. I should be gone by midnight.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, Harold! What a fuss this is.  So unnecessary.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Maude, please. Don't die. I couldn't bear it. Please, don't die.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: But, Harold, we begin to die as soon as we are born. What is so strange about death? It's no surprise. It's part of life. It's change.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But why now?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I thought eighty was a good round number.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: I feel giddy.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But Maude, you don't understand. I love you. Do you hear me? I've never said that to anyone in my life before. You're the first. Maude. Please don't leave me.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, Harold, don't upset yourself so.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's true. I can't live without you.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: "And this too shall pass away."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Never! Never! I'll never forget you. I wanted to marry you. Don't you understand! I love you. I love you!

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh! That's wonderful, Harold. Go - and love some more.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Chardin. Dame Marjorie. But you may call me Maude.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Please! She has got to see a doctor right away.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Please, don't you realize? She is dying.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, not <u>dying</u>, actually. I'm changing. You know, like from winter to spring. Of course, it is a big step to take.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Of course, Harold's father had a similar sense of the absurd. I remember once in Paris he stepped out for cigarettes and the next I hear he's arrested for floating nude down the Seine - experimenting in river currents with a pair of yellow rubber water wings. Well, that cost quite a little bit of "enfluence" and "d'argent" to hush up, I can tell you. Harold, dear, stop playing with your food. Don't you feel well?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I have a sore throat.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Well, I want you to go to bed directly after dinner. You know how susceptible you are to colds. Harold has always been a delicate child. Even as a baby he seemed to be abnormally prone to illness - Harold, dear, eat up your beets...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Mother.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Not now, Harold...  You can't put me down for Monday?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Mother.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Harold, please! I'm on the phone.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Mother. I'm going to get married.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Fay, I'll call you back.  What did you say?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm getting married.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: To whom?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: To a girl. Here.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: I suppose you think this is very funny, Harold.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: A sunflower?

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Love? Love? What do you <u>know</u> about her? Where does she come from? Where did you meet her?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: At a funeral.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Oh... That's wonderful... I get an eighty-year-old pallbearer for a daughter-in-law! Be reasonable, Harold! You're dealing with your life! What will people say?!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't care what people say.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: You don't care! "Miss Shroud of 1890 Weds the Boy of a Thousand Deaths!" Listen to me...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm going to marry the woman I love.

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: Harold!

turns.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
turns.text: This is insane.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Perhaps it is.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How do you do?

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Can't complain.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Would you like a cigarette?

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: No, thank you. They stain my fingers.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Is Sunshine your real name?

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Well, actually, it was the name of my drama teacher - Louis Sunshine. Perhaps you've heard of him. He was such an influence on the development of my instrument. That means my body - in theatre talk. Well, when I came to Hollywood I felt the need to express the emerging me in a new form, so I took on "Sunshine." Dore is my real name... Well, Dore, actually. My, what a lovely place you have here.

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Do you play?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No. I'm learning the banjo. Do you?

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Oh, I studied the guitar. I had to give it up. Gave me calluses on my fingers. As an actress I can't afford to have a tarnished instrument.

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Oh, is this your father?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No. My uncle.

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Oh, he's in the Army. I do so like the military, don't you? Those uniforms make men look so virile. I did "What Price Glory?" in summer stock. I played Charmaine - with a French accent.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: This one is particularly interesting. It's a hari-kari blade.

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Ohhh. What's hari-kari?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: An ancient Japanese ceremony.

turns.speaker: SUNSHINE
turns.text: Like a tea ceremony?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No. Like this.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Tell me, Harold, how many of these, eh, suicides have you performed?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: An accurate number would be difficult to gauge.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: And why is that?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, some worked out better than others - some had to be abandoned in the planning stages - do you include the first time? - then there's the question of maiming...

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Just give me a rough estimate.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, a rough estimate... I'd say fifteen.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Fifteen.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: A rough estimate.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: And were they all done for your mother's benefit?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I wouldn't say "benefit."

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: No, I suppose not. How do you feel about your mother?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't think I'm getting through to Mother like I used to.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Does that worry you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes. It does.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I put a lot of effort into these things.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Ah, yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And a lot of time.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: I'm sure. But what else do you do with your time? Do you go to school?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: What about the draft?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: My mother spoke to my Uncle Victor. He's in the Army and he fixed it up.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Oh. Well, how do you spend your day?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You mean when I'm not working on a...

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Yes. What kind of things do you do?
